comment.author: 30484128@N03
comment._content:
I'll guess it was "The Prince of Paris."

In keeping with the idea of a virtual prize, "The Prince of Paris" is a virtual play but it sounds like the title of something that would have been produced at an Ursuline Convent in 1927.

comment.author: 49925342@N02
comment._content: Clearly Romeo & Juliet as The Montagues one side, the Capulets the other, with R &J in the middle and Friar Lawrence with great beard, Friar John and the Nurse in a big nursey hat!

comment.author: 30484128@N03
comment._content: I defer to the compelling logic of the mermaid tavern.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Me too, unless someone else has more compelling evidence? It's the "big nursey hat" that clinches it! Still, there're other plays with warring sides, so maybe someone else has a suggestion...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: That's in beautiful condition, thanks Stu.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] Thanks. I actually passed this one over because of the enamel damage. In the event , it sold cheaply for £7.99 + P&P. If I knew it would sell for that low price I would have put in a bid. With hindsight as usual, ah well - c'est la vie!
Stuart.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: A terrific shot.  The moustaches were not only necessary for the period in question but also for the girls to look less girlish.  The lassy just behind Juliet  looks the most convincing.
